General Social survey Sai Prashanth Pathi, Vishwas Reddy Thuniki, Nishi Modi 2021-12-11 Chapter 1 Introduction As a part of EDAV course final project, we would be analyzing the general social factors of United States like age, race, religion, martial status, etc. Through this analysis we aim to explain trends in American behaviors, demographics, and opinions. We would be trying to answer questions like: How the average income change over the years? How does income distribute across different age groups and its change over time? Did any race show significant growth in income compared to others? Does marital status have an effect on income? Does watching more TV suggest lower income? Do old people tend to watch more TV than younger people? Does marital status affect the amount of time someone watches TV? Is there a significant income difference between different races, parties, denominations and religions? If not, was there any such difference in the past? Are there any dependencies between religion and political parties?

Chapter 2 Data sources The data has been downloaded from https://gssdataexplorer.norc.org/. The General Social Survey (GSS) is a project of NORC at the University of Chicago, with principal funding from the National Science Foundation. Since 1972, the GSS has been monitoring societal change and studying the growing complexity of American society. The GSS is a publicly available national resource, and is one of the most frequently analyzed sources of information in the social sciences. The data has 21483 records and 9 variables. Variables are as follows- Year, age and tvhours are numerical. rincome is categorical in income range. marital status, race, party affiliation, religion, denomination are categorical variables.
